texts.definition: The penalty in a game of losing a life.
markups: <style="Definition">The penalty in a game of losing a life.</style>

Lives are used in some games to allow players to fail a couple of times before the game session or game instance terminates, i.e. they can fail as long as they have lives left. <style="CurrentLink">Life Penalties</style> are penalties given to players that remove one of these lives and thereby move players closer to having their gameplay end.

Getting caught by ghosts in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style> makes players lose lives. Likewise, getting hit in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style> or having all ones cities destroyed in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Missile%20Command">Missile Command</link></style> removes lives from the players.

<style="CurrentLink">Life Penalties</style> is a specific type of <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> that is typically used in games with <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="fudged-results">Fudged Results</link></style> can be used to allow players or others (such as <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>) to remove individual cases of <style="CurrentLink">Life Penalties</style>; if this can be done too often the pattern however in practice removes the possibility of <style="CurrentLink">Life Penalties</style>.

The main design issue with <style="CurrentLink">Life Penalties</style> is if they should be handed out directly as effects of <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> or if they are the cumulative effects of <style="Link"><link="energy-penalties">Energy Penalties</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Life Penalties</style> are <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>. As long as players still have <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> left, they need to be followed by <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> to replace players' <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> (unless the <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> are non-diegetic of course). Whenever they trigger and players have no more <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> to lose, they also instantiate <style="Link"><link="game-termination-penalties">Game Termination Penalties</link></style> (or else the <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> pattern do not have its traditional meaning). This also means that <style="CurrentLink">Life Penalties</style> indirectly can cause <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style>. Risking to lose <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> makes players feel <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and even more so when one only has one <style="Link"><link="lives">Life</link></style> left.
